duck.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a very common water bird with short legs and a wide beak, used for its meat, eggs, and soft feathers
duck.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the meat of a duck used as food
duck.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to speak to someone, especially a woman, in a friendly way
duck.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: What can I get you, ducks?
duck.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: a score of zero by a batsman in a game of cricket
duck.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The ducks on the river started quacking.
Ducks were waddling across the grass.
Ducks and swans paddled towards us.
A single wild duck was swimming and diving.
They watched the ducks bobbing up and down on the waves.
The park has a duck pond which the children like.
duck.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to lower your head or body very quickly, especially to avoid being seen or hit
duck.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: If she hadn’t ducked, the ball would have hit her.
Tim ducked down to comb his hair in the mirror.
She ducked her head to look more closely at the inscription.
Jamie saw his father coming and ducked quickly behind the wall.
duck.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to move somewhere very quickly, especially to avoid being seen or to get away from someone
duck.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The two men ducked into a block of flats and disappeared.
She ducked out of the door before he could stop her.
‘Wait a minute’, he called, ducking back inside.
duck.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to avoid something, especially a difficult or unpleasant duty
duck.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The ruling body wanted to duck the issue of whether players had been cheating.
Glazer ducked a question about his involvement in the bank scandal.
duck.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to push someone under water for a short time as a joke
duck.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Tom grabbed him from behind to duck him under the surface.
